Description: Body sherd of North Ionian black-figured pottery plate; sets of grooves towards centre on underside; glaze fired red-brown; on floor, cream slip; decoration arranged in two friezes, separated by thick band with added red stripe lined in white; upper frieze: lower parts of probably two sphinxes to left; lower frieze: part of sphinx to right (only wing preserved); filling ornaments: roughly drawn blobs; added red patches on thigh, belly and alternate feathers of sphinxes' wings; incision used for details of sphinxes and rosettes. Drill hole in broken edge from sampling for analysis. Pinkish-light brown clay with some lime inclusions and a fair amount of small silver mica.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Probably from same plate as Heidelberg, Antikenmuseum, I81.
Bibliographic references: CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (II D, pl. IV, 48)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.720)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.701, table 8.18, no.20)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
